text: Good morning everyone and welcome to
amplifying the Unreal audio engine with
extensions and plugins. This talk is
about how to squeeze as much juice as
possible out of the Unreal audio engine
and customize it to your game or your
interactive experience. So I'm Jay. I'm
tech director at Swedish where we
develop boutique audio technologies that
enable teams to implement and deliver
worldclass audio. And we are Alvin,
Alex, Conra, Gustaf, myself, Pete and
Steve. We're also part of Sweet Justice
Sound which means we get to work with
the amazing amazing cadre of sound
designers there and we are really
privileged to work on so many awesome
projects alongside them.
So today I'm going to break this talk uh
about amplifying Unreal audio into three
parts. First I'll go over why we think
Unreal audio is so amplifiable. Then
we'll look at how we've made use of this
power at Swedish in work that we've
already released and this will be the
main bulk of the talk. Uh, and finally,
I'll cover what we're currently
investigating and exploring. So, I hope
you take away from this talk a sense of
the opportunities you have to customize
and soup up Unreal audio with some
concrete examples of things that worked
for us and also some stuff that didn't
work out and why it didn't work out. Um,
I also hope you're inspired to try to
improve your workflows and tools and
that this sparks some creativity for you
and your team.
First up, why?
So, first and foremost, we really like
the paradigm of UEI audio. The fact that
it's centered around node-based sound
design. And of course, metaounds is a
power tool for sound design. And it
gives you such flexibility to create
interactive sound objects and make them
work and sound the way you want them to.
So, also several folks at Swedish have
experience working in a similar
nodebased paradigm in a previous uh
company life using an in-house engine.
And this kind of gave us the confidence
and some of the knowledge to create
amazing sounding games using this.
With Unreal audio, you can kind of go
from simplicity to complexity with the
range of like tools and ways to play
sound that Unreal audio offers. So, a
key part of the system for me is that
you can just play waves if you want to.
They are sound assets when you import
them in the same way that a meta sound
is a sound asset and the system treats
them in the same way at like a
fundamental level. So because of this,
you can prototype and work quickly if
you need to by just throwing wave files
in. And then while your project grows
and and scales, you can handle that
increase in complexity with more complex
asset types like metaound sources and
patches and that kind of thing. The
engine is highly extensible. So this
means it's been designed and engineered
to allow you great creative and
technical freedom to integrate your
ideas and your preferences and your
workflows into what has already been
built.
It provides a great suite of default
functionality, which is definitely
enough to get the project off the ground
and into production. But part of the
genius of this extensibility that I
talked about is how it allows you to
override the built-in functionality in
some cases and just provide your own. So
this means if you have differing needs
to what the engine provides, you're not
fighting the system. You're only limited
by what you can imagine and the amount
of engineering time you can devote to
what you can imagine.
So why should you as audio professionals
extend the Unreal audio engine?
There are always going to be specific
requirements for each project for audio.
So things are going to be different
between first and third person games,
shooters and action adventures, racing,
puzzle games, whatever. And within these
genres, um, individual titles will have
things they want to focus on
specifically and push the boundaries
for. And with the best will in the
world, there's no single audio engine
that could support all these different
requirements out of the box. And that's
where the extensibility that I talked
about comes in. So it allows you to
leverage the hard work of the engine
team that build these very solid
foundations and some really powerful
tools that go on top of that whilst also
taking the whole thing in your own
direction.
We're all different and our brains work
in their own unique and amazing and
weird ways. And because of this, we all
prefer different workflows when we're
working. So customizing an existing
workflow to our needs or creating a
totally custom flow pretty much always
improves iteration time. And when we can
iterate faster, we can get to better
sounding things.
And I know the UEI audio team is packed
with, you know, world experts making
cutting edge audio tech, but they can't
be everywhere all at once. And the
engine allows you to bring your own
specialized experience to the table for
your project.
And finally, you might be working on a
platform or a piece of hardware that the
engine has not been able to extract the
most out of yet. Um, and extending gives
you the opportunity to plug things
together in a way that might not have
been explored yet or might be really
project specific and in fact not
appropriate to go in the engine. And
overall, it just feels like an audio
programmer's playgrounds to me. There's
so much of the engine is accessible and
overridable. It's just great fun to work
with as an audio programmer.
So, on to then who can do this as uh who
can extend the Unreal audio engine. So,
like everything gamedev related, you
need programmers for a lot of this
stuff. And when I say programmers, I
mean people comfortable working with
C++. You don't necessarily have to be
like a battle hardened DSP engineer to
do this since many of the extension
points are really self-contained and
allow you to be very specific about uh
what you're doing without having to
scaffold too much around it.
Technical sound designers who don't code
can also do a huge amount with
blueprints and of course with metasounds
um and in blueprints whether it be by
extending existing structures that are
already there hooking into engine
delegates or using editor utility
blueprints and widgets to create uh
workflows within the editor.
And in my experience as well,
nontechnical sound designers are usually
itching to create workflows and engine
behavior extensions, but they don't
always have the knowledge or the
confidence of how to implement them. And
this is where collaboration really kicks
into overdrive. And when audio
programmers and technical sound
designers can find find ways to empower
sound designers to create the things
they need, that's where the like magic
really happens.
So now we're going to look at how
Swedish Techch have approached using
these extension points and tell some
development stories about our process
for using them.
We already have several plugins that
vary in size and scope including the
audio inspector which has now thankfully
been largely superseded by the uh by
audio insights but this is this was our
kind of first step towards getting
towards that and now audio insights is
starting to surpass it which is awesome.
So but we released that a little while
ago. Um, there's our HDR, high dynamic
range, uh, mixing plugin, ambience, and
we also have a bunch of utility and
experimental plugins that we're working
with. And something they all have in
common is their usage of the engine's
extensibility.
So, we'll take a look at these three
plugins along the timeline of when
Swedish released them. And first up, the
audio inspector briefly.
So, the audio inspector is a plugin that
shows details of the active sounds
playing in Unreal audio engine at a
glance within the editor.
I've already talked quite a lot in
detail about this plug-in and how we
made use of the editor's UI
extensibility at Unreal Fest 23 in a
talk called Building the Audio
Inspector. So, if you want more detail,
please check out that talk online in the
editor uh sorry Unreal um community. But
it's still I think extremely worthwhile
talking about extending the editor in
the context of uh this talk because it's
the primary tool we have to create and
customize workflows. So, Unreal's native
C++ UI system is called Slate. It's very
powerful state-based UI system and I
think if you don't get stuck into it,
you're probably leaving something on the
table workflow-wise and like many UI
systems, it's hierarchical. So widgets
are the self-contained unit of rendering
and logic. Any all the things you see
here are at some point widgets and
windows in UEIE, that whole thing is a
window can um can host any type of
widget.
And this widgets can also host any type
of widget which allows you to make more
or less whatever you can design because
you can structure things in whatever way
you want. It's widgets all the way down.
And right at the bottom of the chain
there are leaf widgets which know how to
render themselves and they allow you to
do custom drawings. So anything that's
rendering text is a leaf widget. Any of
the the pictures are leaf widgets just
how you arrange them on the page and
what how you feed them data.
There are lots of pre-made and uh layout
and functional widget types. So, it's
worth checking out whether something
already exists in the engine before
trying to make it yourself since there
probably already is something like it.
And there's also a bunch of audio
specific widgets that you can use to
make nice familiar audio looking tools
if you're into that.
UMG widgets are blueprint wrappers
around Slate widgets. So, you can use
these to make um editor utility widgets
from and anything that can be made with
UMG can be made in Slate. So it means
that UMG is a really powerful
prototyping tool as well for um for
stuff you then want to bake down into
code in Slate. Unfortunately, you can't
go the other way around unless you
provide your own wrapper around a Slate
widget for UMG, which is a good way to
do things. And if you have something
that's kind of reusable, you can put a
UMG wrapper around it and use it
elsewhere.
So that was really brief, but that's the
audio inspector and how we made it. And
now let's look at our HDR plugin. So
first off, I want to talk about what I
mean by HDR or high dynamic range. So in
our case, it's a loudness-based dynamic
mixer where sounds are individually
metered at runtime and mixed based on
some simple rules around their metered
values and the system as a whole. And
conceptually, it's designed to mimic the
stipedius reflex in your ears, which
happens when they start to detect that a
loud sound might cause your ears some
damage. And they constrict the path to
the eardrum to provide natural
attenuation. So this is kind of an
attempt by your body to make it safe to
listen to a wider range of dynamics in
the real world. And mimicking this
behavior allows us to represent a wider
dynamic range of sounds within the
inherently limited medium of playing
sound back through speakers.
So in the system we allow you to attach
a loudness value to each sound asset in
dB SPL and it can go all the way from 0
to 220 dB. Although this is a really
extreme range like that would destroy
your actual ears. So in the game you
really need to use anything more than
like between 40 and about 150 dB to get
what you need.
Each instance of a HDR sound is then
metered at that runtime in dBFS and a
conceptual loudness in dB SPL is
calculated from that and this is used to
calculate the loudness of the whole HDR
system together which by default kind of
rests at 80 dB because that's where the
stedious reflex kicks in in most people.
Then louder sounds move the current
loudness of the system up and all of the
sounds are mixed down by the difference
between this level and the resting
level. That's pretty simple in in uh in
concept, but the complexity is how it
actually gets all those um metered
levels.
This has the effect of maintaining
loudness relationships between sounds
while making space in the mix for the
louder sounds. This implies that there's
also a positive correlation between
loudness and the importance of the
sound, which you know, conceptually
debatable, but this definitely the
system does this for you. Um it's also
not a compressor or a ducking mixer for
this reason because the loudness
relationships are maintained.
So when we were planning this system, we
took a lot of learnings about how the
engine is put together from the audio
inspector. So displaying something for
debug purposes is a great way to learn
how it works for yourself. So I'd
recommend whipping something up like
this if you have the time to really
grasp the structure of UE Audio. And we
knew we needed to make the most use the
most fundamental part of the engine's
whole extensibility framework and make
this into a plug-in since we knew we'd
want to share this technology between
projects without having to do any costly
engine customization and then port that
engine customization every time. But
this implies or this implied that we
could only implement HDR by making use
of the extension points that the audio
engine provides. Happily, there were
many relevant extension points that can
be used to implement mixing within the
engine and uh those that we required
some tweaks and help to were supported
by the UE audio team who yeah, as you
probably know, are a very open and
outward facing group. So, yeah, do get
in touch with them if you need extra
support and stuff.
And we identified some things that HDR
needed. So, we needed to be able to opt
into the system. We wanted it to be as
light touch as possible on the game
since uh other HDR workflows can
necessitate a lot of heavy hand
authoring and they're pretty holistic
like you either HDR your mix or you
don't but we didn't think it had to be
this way. We also needed to be able to
author data individually per sound asset
so we can define loudness and other
aspects of uh of mixing for the sound
like post game and that kind of thing.
We knew we'd need to be able to
intercept a sound as it was started by
the engine and do something to it.
probably attach a metering uh something
to it and also keep track of it in our
in our system.
And the concept of HDR requires a
centralized mixing system which is
scoped to the lifetime of the audio
device. In other words, it exists for
the whole lifetime of the game or the PI
session or the editor or whatever.
We knew we'd need to apply the results
of the mix calculation as granularly as
possible every audio render frame so as
to avoid avoid uh audibly stepping the
volume. And to handle content at scale,
sound designers need to be able to group
HDR sounds into categories whose values
behave hierarchically uh to allow
broadstrokes mixing with fine grain
control.
Now I'll talk a little bit about the
prototyping process for HDR. So we tried
using a meter analyzer as our first
attempt which is part of audio synthesia
plugin to meter the sounds and this was
attached to the active sounds during its
creation call back and we tried using
the results of this per sound peak
amplitude analysis to drive the system
loudness calculations which we then
applied to the volume multiplier of the
property of the active sound. Uh that's
the first thing we tried anyway and it
didn't work. Uh there was a feedback
loop between the metered amplitude and
the volume multiplier which caused
volume thrashing for sounds that weren't
the loudest in the system. And from this
we learned that active sounds don't
really provide a way to control volume
independently of their analysis. Um
along with this we found that the meter
analyzer works asynchronously and
reports back at an interval in seconds
which is still really short but the
latency was too much uh inherent in this
process would be too much for how uh HDR
could work as we intended it to.
So our next attempt was to replace usage
of the analyzer with a subclass of a
source effect inserted at the end of the
effect chain of a sound as HDR starts
and it does both metering and mixing of
the sound in the HDR system. This broke
the feedback loop and it was frame
latent which we considered acceptable
but nope it didn't work properly with
sounds as they attenuated over distance.
So distance attenuation in this context
was ignored as source effects are
applied pre-distance attenuation in the
chain and we could sense a chicken and
egg situation developing slightly here.
So for the third attempt we tried to
reimplement distance attenuation
behavior within the source effect that
we made and programmatically disable
distance attenuation for all HDR sounds.
And yeah that seemed to work pretty well
and uh a damn it. Yeah, the attenuation
volume is used to inform culling
behavior and provide other information
to the rest of the audio engine.
And we found from this that HDR needs to
be able to control attenuation volume
and sometimes force it higher to prevent
sounds with high loudness from being
attenuated when they're the loudest in
the system. Like if they're further away
but still the loudest, they would get
distance attenuation, which we didn't
want.
So, thank goodness for the source data
override audio engine plugin. If I'm not
mistaken, uh this was designed for
simulating acoustic propagation and was
initially used by project acoustics or
project Triton depending on who you ask.
And you can use it to alter any of the
properties of a running f-wave instance,
which is just an instance of the
soundwave assets when they're currently
playing in the engine. In our case,
we're using it to override the
attenuation distance property of HDR
sounds only. And these are applied post
logic but pre-render. So you don't get
any problems with data being stomped and
you don't get feedback loops because all
these overrides just go away every
single render frame and you have to
reapply them. So it's very safe in that
uh regard. And this is a little cool GIF
of Project Acoustics which it was made
for. And this ended up being the
architecture we shipped with. This
extension is really powerful because you
can basically do anything to running
sounds with it. So great power comes
great responsibility, massive foot guns
and all that kind of thing. But it's
it's really cool. You should check it
out if you want to do some mixing stuff.
So next we settled on some structure for
the HDR plug-in. And to add HDR data to
individual sound assets, we use what's
called an asset user data. These this is
an enginewide concept that allows you to
attach your own data types to engine
assets, effectively making them
extensible data types without requiring
you to subclass them, which is a really
tedious and and long process to do.
Soundbased assets implement this
pattern. So whoever made that decision
in the engine team, thank you so much.
That's awesome. Uh this uh solution
worked particularly well at scale as
well compared to other more centralized
options like having a data table and
attaching data to it that way. Um
because if you use game feature plugins
for example uh data can disappear when
they're not loaded and then you end up
with missing references in data tables.
Whereas with asset user data the data is
always there attached to the asset when
you need it.
It also uses an audio subsystem as its
centralized logic point. So when you
write an audio subsystem, they're
automatically created uh at the same
time as an audio device whenever the
game client or Pi starts. And it also it
also runs in the editor alongside the
editor's audio device. And they tick on
the audio thread, which is great news
because uh they can directly access
audio engine data and make changes in a
thread safe way. You don't need to worry
about any thread concerns if you have
one of these things running. It also
doesn't use game thread CPU time
unnecessarily. So you don't have to
sustain the IR of a technical director
asking for critical CPU time back on the
game thread, which is great.
We found that it's possible to intercept
active sounds as they start by
implementing the I active sound update
interface. As active sounds are created,
deleted, virtualized, and realized they
invoke the interface functions here. And
your code that implements this gets
notified. And so we implemented this on
our HDR subsystem which then registers
the sound as it starts with the HDR
system and attaches the sub uh source
effect to it.
And as things developed, we knew we
wanted to be able to control the mix at
runtime as well as let the system mix.
So HDR sounds have that static loudness
value in DBSPL authored for each of them
as I mentioned. However, it's always
going to be the case that with a mix
system, you'll need to apply dynamic
changes at runtime to the mix based on
the game state or mix choices, whatever.
So, we wanted to make sure there was a
way to do this through blueprints as you
might expect, but also uh allowing it to
be through metaound outputs since some
logical calculation can take place
within a metaound graph. You can have
like a first person or third person
switch for example in a metaound and
this can change dynamically and you
might want to alter the loudness of the
playing sound based on that.
So in order to do this through
blueprints, you have to expose code to
the blueprint editor. The easiest way to
make something available to a subsystem
uh from a subsystem to blueprints is to
tag a function with U function blueprint
callable, which works, but you always
have to then get the subsystem in
blueprints before you can call any of
these functions, which is like another
five more clicks. It's really tedious.
It's in danger of breaking flow, which
we don't want to do. So to get around
that, we created what's called a
blueprint function library that wraps
all of the U function tag functions on
the subsystem inside static accessible
anywhere functions doing the tedious
part of getting the active HDR subsystem
uh in code for you. So you don't have to
do it. All you have to do is just pull
the function that you want like override
loudness at this point or clear loudness
overrides or whatever.
The other way we gathered mix offset
data was by using a metasound interface
to allow sound designers to write offset
values from inside the metaounds. So
interfaces formalize the name of a
metaound input or output. So you can
always be sure that you're sending data
to the right thing or receiving data
from the right place. So in our case it
was called swedtech.hdr. loudness
modifier. You know that's going to be
what you need. Um, and this interface is
listened to in the HDR subsystem when
calculating individual sounds loudness
values and the values applied additively
to the static loudness for each sound,
which then goes on to affect the
subsystem loudness calculations.
And like I said, and uh right now
metasound interfaces are defined in code
kind of like this. Uh, but I believe the
plan is that you'll be able to define
them in project data, which would allow
technical sound designers to get in on
the action of using these things, which
is really cool. So, I'm looking forward
to that.
and editor side for HDR, we had several
workflows as opposed to just the one for
audio inspector. So, we wanted to be
able to author,
monitor, and visualize the system from
within these workflows. And at the core
of our monitoring and authoring
workflows are Slate Slist and S
hierarchical list view uh widgets, which
present lists and hierarchies based on
any data structure that you provide,
which is going to be in this case just
an array. And with the hierarchical
view, it gives you callbacks to kind of
generate a hierarchy from that. This
really brief explanation glosses over
that they are actually quite a lot of
work to implement and take a lot of
time. Uh but they're really worth it
when you do. And if you do end up
implementing one of these things, I'd
thoroughly recommend you use a model
view view model pattern. A little bit
more about that is in that talk I
referenced earlier, building the audio
inspector. Again, go check it out if you
want to know more.
And for visualizing the system, we used
an S-leaf widget to do its own custom
rendering. So, this was cool because we
wanted to do something very bespoke that
wasn't supported by the engine. We
wanted to just draw all these um
loudness lines based on what was going
on in the subsystem. To do that, there's
a lot of helper code for common UI
rendering tasks like draw a line between
this point and that point, which we
built all our stuff on. And this really
all came together to build a flow that
allows hierarchical mixing of HDR sounds
with an inspector, monitoring, and debug
tools in the editor.
And along with this, we have a suite of
tests that makes use of the automation
test framework of Unreal Engine. And the
main idea of these tests is to prevent
regressions. Yeah, I know. I know it's
early. Come on. It's okay. Tests are
tests are really cool. They are super
awesome for making sure you don't have
to worry about stuff when you're fixing
problems. Uh so there are two main kinds
of tests we use to achieve this. There's
unit tests, which are small code-defined
tests written to check individual small
parts of functionality of some code. So
we use them mainly to test our maths
code and algorithm reliability and
sometimes do some opaque system testing
down to the function or the class level
and you can run them through the
automation test framework in the editor
or you can set up on the command line to
run. And then there are functional tests
which are blueprints made by usually
technical sound designers which reside
in uh some test level and these in our
case make use of envelope followers to
track the expected level of sounds in
certain contexts. So this is cool
because you're kind of uh you know
opaquely testing the entire system from
a sound point of view and it has the
benefit of making them audible. So you
can naturally test stuff with your ears
by just setting it running and sitting
and listening to it as well as letting
it be tested by the numbers. So that's
cool cuz sometimes if you're testing
something you have to manually repeat
the process. You don't really
necessarily want to be doing that and
also trying to listen to it. Um, so
yeah, these are pretty cool. And the
unit tests in particular made use of
another engine extension point which I'm
really excited about, which is the
metaound builder API. So this allows you
to create metaounds at runtime via C++
or blueprint using this kind of code.
Uh, and in our case, we use it just to
manufacture test metaounds so that we
don't have to include any data in
plugins to support the tests. But I'm
sure there are many more, in fact, I
know there are many more creative uses
of the metaound builder API out there.
The game mix universe is basically one
massive use of this thing. Um, and I'll
I'll leave that as an exercise for the
listener to figure out all the other
cool ways of using this stuff. So, I've
talked a long time about HDR and now I'm
going to actually play some HDR system
running. So, what you're going to hear
is the ambiences kind of just sitting
away below the resting level and then
some loud things are going to come in
and blow the cobwebs off and then you'll
hear the the ambulances come back in
again after the system is. So, let's go.
battery standing.
[Applause]
Reinforcement
[Music]
It's cool because as well as hearing it
with your ears, you can kind of see
what's going on. And like I know like
sound designers and audio people always
need the visuals to like back up what
we're hearing. So we're not just like,
"Did you really hear this? Yes, you
really heard this really happened."
So to recap, we used a lot of extensions
in the process of creating the HDR
plug-in, and those are subsystems,
source effects, audio analyzers, why did
I make this so fast? audio analyzers,
active sound update interface, source
data override, blueprint function
libraries, metasound interfaces, and the
metaound builder API.
So, onto the plugin we released earlier
this year, Ambience.
I'll start again with a little overview
of what our ambience plug-in does. So,
at its core, the system allows you to
author complex soundscapes and volumes
in with with volume, sorry, inside a
game world.
It uses distance to the listener to the
volume to fade ambient beds in and out
and it blends and mixes between them
using a priority value that you set on
the on the uh on the volumes. Spot
sounds are scattered in around the
listener based on sets of logic defined
on the volumes and in assets and reverb
sends and area types parameters are
blended using distance as well.
So, this plug-in was developed initially
for uh an in-house project at Sweet
Justice that is a large open world title
where there needs to be a sense of
scale, but also lots of intimate details
of a livedin place. And we knew we
needed to have distance-based
crossfading rather than timebased
boundary crossfades as this really
increases tangibility and interactivity
of the soundscapes. like they they
really sound more me uh more real if you
can feel the change as you're moving
between them rather than just kind of
ticking over a boundary and then hearing
the the change over time. So to help
achieve this, we wanted to be able to
swap and blend content inside metaound
instances based on some parameters
supplied automatically from the ambience
system from outside. And we also wanted
to be able to blend reverb sends based
on distance as well. For the same reason
that we want to blend content on
distance, we knew we'd need to
autoscatter those spot sounds to add
depth and detail to the soundsscape. And
as with everything we do, it would need
to be highly inspectable and debugable
so that sound designers working on the
system can just see exactly what's going
on at a glance.
So when we were planning it, we realized
it's a system that's much more gameplay
audio than HDR in that it interacts with
other gameplay systems and level design
features of the engine at a much sort of
higher level. And some as a result of
this, some of the system is made from
parts of the gameplay framework or in
other words from actors and actor
components. And it follows from this
that it has to exist in the game world
with a capital W and be spatial and
volutric in nature in a way that HDL was
not. We also realized we'd need to
create asset types to manage the
complexity of this system and make use
